comments.body: Is it OK to have asarray applied after the the `==` operator rather than applying it to the operands?
Yeah, but the asarray can be just removed here, since in both functions a1 and a2 are already converted to arrays before this line.

@seberg If the two operands are 0d arrays, the == operator will return a bool object instead of an array, in which case the call to all() will fail. I could add a special case for this though, if unnecessarily calling asarray() is too costly.

Just realized I need to handle this properly in array_equal() too.

Ah, right. The performance of asarray is no worry to me (it just returns immediately since it is already an array anyway). It might be that all works on the np.bool_ object, but I don't care either way then.

I added asarray call to array_equal too. My reasoning that I stated earlier wasn't quite correct. The == operator actually returns a np.bool_ object for 0d arrays, but returns a False object for two arrays that don't broadcast.
Could also use `axisa = axisb = axisc = axis` but not important (not sure what PEP8 says about it).

Just noticed this is still open, sorry for forgetting about it (dunno if it was me who reviewed it first). Mostly some thoughts left.

comments.body: Question (seriously, and annoying ;)). `np.transpose` uses the `wrapit` logic. You are basically explicitly circumventing it here (otherwise could just call np.transpose after all?). Is that intentional? Do we still like `wrapit` at all?
I also need `a.ndim` to be valid, so I need to do the coercion to ndarray before the transpose.

I agree with @seberg that one might as well try to remain consistent with previous logic. Why not simply duck type and remove the whole clause and call `np.transpose` at the end? I do think it is fine for `numpy` functions to assume that whatever is passed in will have an `ndim` attribute (and `rollaxis` does the same).

Well, `np.transpose` can handle (lists of) lists, e.g.,

```
In [2]: np.transpose([[0, 1], [2, 3]])
Out[2]:
array([[0, 2],
       [1, 3]])
```

So it seems somewhat logical to be able to handle nested lists in `moveaxis` as well. I even have a unit test verifying this. I don't feel too strongly about this, but I do think it's a bit more consistent.

Well, I guess you are right, it was a bit silly. I thought transpose was better about preserving subclasses. But since a subclass must have the `.transpose` attribute it should never go into the second branch (where the "wrap" could be missing for some subclass support).
So on first sight I think it is good, but will ponder it a bit more.

comments.body: I wonder about stupid objects, but I guess we just shouldn't care, anyone who wants to do `np.full(3, (1, 2))` should be prepared to give `dtype=object`. (could make it `copy=False` just for the kicks)

Well, `np.full(3, (1, 2))` (with or without passing `dtype=object`) didn't work and still doesn't work.  The real fun happens when someone write `np.full(3, (1, 2, 3))` though (it used to, and still, returns `array([1, 2, 3])`).

Is there a function equivalent to `array(fill_value).dtype`, but that would actually return `object` when a non-scalar is passed in?  I thought `np.obj2sctype(..., default=object)` would work, but it returns the dtype of a ndarray when a ndarray is passed in (so `np.full(3, np.array([1, 2, 3]))` would still "fail").  (By the way I find `obj2sctype's` "return None if everything fails" somewhat unpythonic.)

Forget about this, I guess.... object dtype is funny, and you just have to do it manually. Even noticed we had talked about it before, heh. I guess you are right about `obj2sctype`, it might be trying to recreate the corresponding C-function, no idea....
So should we consider that `np.full(3, (1, 2, 3)) ==> np.array([1, 2, 3])` (the old behavior, kept in this patch) is not a stopper?  I feel like there should be a way to at least error out there.

Maybe there should be an error. `arr.fill` kind of tries this, not sure about all the logic it uses.

In any case, this is an orthogonal issue, so I think we should ignore it here.
Really, the only reason I didn't merge it yet, was that I liked our special tag, like ENH:, or actually I guess here MAINT: is better, in the commit message ;).

comments.body: Would be good to add a ..versionadded:: thingy here for the sequence of ints (also slightly prefer sequence over tuple).
I guess it should really be "array-like of ints"?  I kept tuple mostly for consistency with e.g. `np.sum`.

Oh, OK, no I prefer tuple or sequence of ints. Thought we used sequence mostly, but if we use tuple as well, just keep it as it is. It currently is more an "array-like of ints" in implementation, but I don't like that too much to be honest (you could put in a 2x2 array...).

So to be clear. If you don't mind just ignoring the broadcasting for now, I think I would prefer something like:

```
try:
     axes = tuple(axis)
except:
    axes = (axis,)
```

or the inverted `try: operator.index(axis)`. But if the broadcasting is important to you, maybe as is, is just simpler, hmmm.

Well, I did not know that iterating over a broadcast object would result in nd-iteration (i.e. a 2x2 axis would get flattened out at that point).
I still like the broadcasting behavior, though.

I guess you could just check `broadcast(...).shape` to be 0 or 1D and raise an error otherwise, that would seem acceptable to me. Or multiply the length of the tuples manually if they are length 1, but probably that gets annoying.

Coming back to the tuple-vs-sequence issue, I just noticed that `sum`, for example, would error out if a non-tuple sequence is passed as the `axis` argument.  Not sure if that means `sum` should be improved or we should only accept tuples to avoid weird edge cases...

I think it does not matter. In most of the python side stuff, we will allow any sequence and sometimes iterable (tuple(iterable) works). I don't think we have to strife for perfect consistency when it comes to tuples vs. sequences vs. iterables for the this type of arguments.

If you prefer, you can make it a strict tuple here as well, but basically I would pick whatever is easiest.

It seems we got side tracked here and forgot about the versionadded tag. It would be good to mention somewhere that roll along multiple axes was added with this tag. IIRC it could either go here, or also into the Notes section.

comments.body:
Nice find. My pythonesque instincts wants me to write this like
```
for dim, r in zip(dimensions, res):
    r[:] = arange(dim, dtype=dtype).reshape(shape[:i] + (dim,) + shape[i+1:])
```
(no reason to split the line)

But really this is bikeshedding, so feel free to ignore
Split the line because apparently we still worry about 80 chars sometimes. Think zipping is a little less obvious though, and I think that would be clearer as `...` than `:`

Yes we do worry about line length, we are kind of picky about it, although there are some exceptions. Also about spaces around `+ - =', etc., but not around `**` and somewhat optional around `*/`. Other style nits we sometimes ignore in tests for readabilty. Use your judgement about style, but lean towards picky as style deviations otherwise accumulate, and also because we may want to run a style checker for violations in the future. SciPy already does that.
So since this meets line lengths rules, this should be good to merge? I'm guessing it's bad form to merge my own PR
Good that you didn't do the `zip` -- it actually would break some corner cases (when an item is a scalar rather than an array).

comments.body: Does that work when `N == 0`?

Unfortunately it doesn't, because `np.stack` needs at lease one array to stack and fails for `np.stack([])`, so it fails for the `dimensions==()` case. So this needs at least a special path for this case. I still like it more then the old solution, however it is a more severe code change overall.

@Ablinne - multiple options:
1. `return np.stack(...) if N > 0 else np.array([], dtype=dtype)`
2. Stick with what you have.
3. Still make the empty array and loop with the insertions but after creating the tuple:
```
# TODO: once stack allows an empty tuple, this could be replaced with
# np.stack(np.broadcast_arrays(*indices))
res = empty((N,)+dimensions, dtype=dtype)
for r, index in zip(res, indices):
    r[...] = index
return res
```
I am going to stick with the current version

Oh, @Ablinne I forgot, this needs a `.. versionadded:: 1.17` (one empty line, before and after). I suppose depending on how fast 1.17 is, this may also be in 1.18, since I guess we should feature freeze soon (although we rarely did a hard freeze).
